description: Inherited from Middle English heyfre, hayfre, heyfer, from Old English hēahfore, hēahfru, of disputed origin; see the Old English entry for more discussion.

entries.meaning: A young female cow, (particularly) one over one year old but which has not calved.
examples: And the Lord spake unto Moses and unto Aaron, saying, This is the ordinance of the law which the Lord hath commanded, saying, Speak unto the children of Israel, that they bring thee a red heifer without spot, wherein is no blemish, and upon which never came yoke.
Her, whom I shall choose for my heicfar.

entries.meaning: (informal, derogatory, obsolete) A girl or young woman.
examples: I have half a mind to marry that heifer, tho' wives are bothersome critters when you have too many of them.

entries.meaning: (informal, derogatory) A cow: a large, unattractive, unpleasant woman.
examples: My hand was aching to slap that silly heifer. I told her to take her trifling ass down to Burger King and get herself a job flipping burgers...
